18 MAR 2019 ‚Ä¢ CTF

BSidesSF CTF Yay Or Nay Writeup

This is the second in a series of writeups on challenges from the BSidesSF CTF. You can see a writeup of the first challenge, Blink, here

Yay Or Nay was the second mobile challenge in the CTF, this time worth 200 points. Like last time, we start out with a prompt and an apk file. This time the prompt came in a little more handy.

Keep track of places you would love / hate to see, by dropping markers with a simple click. Try YayorNay v1.2 today!

:::: Updated README :::: v 1.0 - Added short press, Yay support - Fix stability issues

v 1.1 - Added long press, Nay support - Add labels

v 1.2 - Populate from DB - Save to DB

To-do - Fix stability issues - Bug fixes - Implement feature to view by day

First things first, let‚Äôs launch the app.

The app opens up with some instructions on how to use it and a button to get started.

clicks get started

Well, looks like our root-enabled emulator image isn‚Äôt going to work out here. Let‚Äôs launch a Google Play Services enabled one! Unfortunately these images are a little more locked down and we won‚Äôt be able to (easily) get root on them.

Ok, so we have a map of San Francisco with a bunch of markers. Let‚Äôs zoom around and see if anything sticks out. This may have been the worst part of the challenge, zooming and panning with an emulator can get tedious üòÑ

Right in the middle of everything there‚Äôs a grid of some sort. It seems like the next step should be to isolate it. I know from the challenge prompt that these pins are being loaded from a database so I‚Äôll go looking for the app‚Äôs sqlite db.

1. Find the package that contains our yayornay app.

2. Switch to that package‚Äôs user

3. Find the app‚Äôs database

4. List the tables in that database

5. Inspect the table schema

We can see that the database has a list of lat,long pairs each with a date and a color. My first guess is that these correspond to the pins we saw on the map. Let‚Äôs dump the data and see what we get.

Looks like a list of dates, coordinates in and around San Francisco, and the hues for green (120) and red(0)! The next thing I did was go off of the prompt Bug fixes - Implement feature to view by day and check each day one by one.

Back up the database, delete any records that don‚Äôt match a given date, reload the app, restore the database, and repeat! Soon enough, on 02/08/2019 we see:

At this point I had more or less no idea what I was looking at. Luckily a teammate connected the dots (pun intended) between a grid 3 rows high and braille!

Using the green pins as raised points, we can decode the flag to Z3lda!

10 MAR 2019 ‚Ä¢ CTF

BSidesSF CTF Blink Writeup

The BSidesSF CTF happened about a week ago! It was the first CTF I‚Äôve tried to compete in and I had a lot of fun on the ‚ñ£ team. This is the first in a series of writeups on the challenges I participated in.

Blink was the first mobile challenge in the event and served as a good introduction. The goal of the mobile challenges is to find a string (the ‚Äúflag‚Äù) using clues hidden in an app. Often the flag is in the app binary itself, but sometimes the challenge may lead you elsewhere afterwards. Blink was a relatively easy ‚Äú101‚Äù challenge, only worth 50 points (the most difficult challenges in the CTF were worth 600 or more).

Analysis

The first step in any challenge to open the prompt. It contained the text Get past the Jedi mind trick to find the flag you are looking for. and a link to an apk file (Android app). I booted up an Android Emulator and used a simple adb command to install the app.

Opening the app presents us with:

If you aren‚Äôt familiar with Android, an activity is similar to a window in a traditional desktop app or a page on a website. The hint is essentially saying we need to navigate to a different page.

The first place we should check for activities is the AndroidManifest.xml file. All of the accessible activities will be listed there. I used Apktool to disassemble the app.

Then I opened up the Android Manifest..

Here we can see two activities: com.example.blink.MainActivity and com.example.blink.r2d2. We know that MainActivity is where we saw Obi Wan earlier because it has an intent filter that makes it the default activity. The next step is to launch the r2d2 activity. Let‚Äôs whip out adb again and see what we can do.

Well, that didn‚Äôt work. Looks like we don‚Äôt have permission to launch this activity. Let‚Äôs try something else!

Because my emulator is running a build of Android without Google Play Services in it, we can easily assume the root user.

And it worked!

The flag was CTF{PUCKMAN}. The end! Tons of credit to @itsC0rg1 for putting the puzzle together, and BSidesSF for hosting.
